questions.question: Gray baby syndrome is associated with the use of which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation: Gray baby syndrome is associated with the use of Chloramphenicol.

questions.question: Chloramphenicol acts by binding to:
questions.explanation: Chloramphenicol acts by binding to the 50s ribosomal subunit.It inhibits the binding of amino acid containing tRNA to acceptor site on 50s subunit of theribosome. This prevents peptide bond formation by inhibiting the interactionbetween peptidyltransferase enzyme and the amino acid.

questions.question: A patient who was diagnosed with meningitis is on chloramphenicol therapy. Which of thefollowing blood dyscrasias as a side effect of this drug?
questions.explanation: The patient is most likely to have aplastic anemia, as it is the most common blood dyscrasiaassociated with the use of chloramphenicol. It can lead to fatal pancytopenia that has a high rateof mortality.Hematological toxicities of chloramphenicol include:• Dose-related toxicity - pancytopenia (anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia)• Idiosyncratic response - aplastic anemiaBlood dyscrasias occurring with chloramphenicol:Aplastic anemia (70%).Hypoplastic anemia•Agranulocytosis• ThrombocytopeniaChloramphenicol remains an alternative drug for the treatment of meningitis caused by H.influenzae, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae in developing countries and also in patients whohave a severe allergy to ß-lactams.467

questions.question: Which of the following antibiotics structurally resembles aminoacyl t-RNA and inhibits theprotein synthesis by premature termination?
questions.explanation: Puromycin structurally resembles aminoacyl t-RNA and inhibits the protein synthesis bypremature termination. It is used as an antibiotic in cell cultures.Option A: Tetracycline binds to the 30s ribosome and prevents attachment of aminoacyl t-RNA tothe acceptor site.Option B: Chloramphenicol binds to the 50s subunit of the ribosome and inhibits the binding ofamino acid containing tRNA to the acceptor site on 50s subunit of the ribosome.Option D: Erythromycin acts by interfering with translocation at the 50s ribosome.

questions.question: Which of the following groups of antibiotics has additional anti-inflammatory andimmunomodulatory activities?
questions.explanation: Macrolides are a group of antibiotics that have additional anti-inflammatory andimmunomodulatory activities.They are being investigated and used in pulmonary diseases for their immunomodulatoryproperties.Examples of macrolide antibiotics:•Erythromycin• Azithromycin•⚫ Clarithromycin

questions.question: An unvaccinated child diagnosed with diphtheria is initiated erythromycin therapy. This drugacts by interfering with:
questions.explanation: Erythromycin acts by interfering with translocation at the 50s ribosome.It does not inhibit the peptide bond formation but the translocation step is inhibited where thepeptidyl t-RNA molecule moves from the acceptor site on the ribosome to the peptidyl donor site.

questions.question: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus during pregnancy and otherwise respectively?
questions.explanation: The drug of choice for a case of scrub typhus during pregnancy is azithromycin. For other patientsthe drug of choice is doxycycline.An alternative treatment option in pregnant women and patients allergic to doxycycline ischloramphenicol.468

questions.question: What is the drug of choice for diphtheria carrier state?
questions.explanation: The drug of choice for diphtheria carrier state is erythromycin.Erythromycin for 7 days is very effective for eradicating the diphtheria carrier state or acuteinfections.

questions.question: What is the rationale for the use of erythromycin in a patient with diabetic gastroparesis?

options.A: It increases cAMP and increases intestinal motility
options.B: It decreases bacterial count in intestinal hypomotility
options.C: It binds to adenyl cyclase and increases intestinal motility
options.D: It binds to motilin receptors and stimulates intestinal motility

questions.explanation: Erythromycin can be used in diabetic gastroparesis as it binds to motilin receptors and stimulatesintestinal motility.It has been used in conditions with hypomotility of the gastrointestinal tract like in postoperativeileus to promote peristalsis and to increase gastric emptying.Erythromycin is used off-label as a prokinetic agent in the intensive care setting and in patientswith diabetic gastroparesis.

questions.question: The chest x-ray of a patient who presented with fever and cough with expectoration is shownbelow. Following discussion, a lincosamide antibiotic is prescribed. Which of the followingwill choose?you
questions.explanation: Clindamycin, a lincosamide is used in the management of lung abscess and anaerobic lung andpleural space infections.Clindamycin is a congener of lincomycin and binds to the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes andinhibits protein synthesis.Option A: Telithromycin is a ketolide antibiotic.Option B: Spectinomycin is an aminocyclitol antibiotic that binds to the 30S subunit of ribosomesand inhibits protein synthesis.Option D: Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic.

questions.question: Which of the following is a serious adverse effect you would consider as a possibility in apatient receiving clindamycin?
questions.explanation: Clindamycin use is to be limited because of the risk of pseudomembranous colitis.Pseudomembranous colitis is a lethal syndrome caused by Clostridium difficile due to alterationin normal intestinal microbiota. It is characterized by fever, watery diarrhea and increasedperipheral white blood cell count. Metronidazole and oral vancomycin are used in the treatmentof this condition.Drugs causing pseudomembranous colitis are:• Penicillins•⚫ Clindamycin• Rifaximin469•Tetracycline (rare side effect)• Erythromycin

questions.question: Which of the following statements about streptogramins is true?

options.A: Quinupristin-dalfopristin combination is not active against gram-positive cocci
options.B: Synergistic activity of quinupristine and dalfopristine has bactericidal action
options.C: Quinupristin binds to the 30s subunit of ribosomes.
options.D: Dalfopristin binds to the 30s subunit of ribosomes

questions.explanation: Quinupristin and dalfopristin are a combination of streptogramins and the synergistic activity ofthese drugs has bactericidal action.Quinupristin binds to the 50s subunit of ribosomes and acts similar to macrolides by interferingin translocation and inhibiting protein synthesis.Dalfopristin binds to a site nearby, resulting in conformational changes in the 50S ribosomethereby increasing the activity of quinupristin. The synergic activity of these drugs can havebactericidal action in certain susceptible bacteria.Quinupristin/dalfopristin is active against gram-positive cocci and organisms responsible foratypical pneumonia (e.g., M. pneumoniae, Legionella spp., and C. pneumoniae).Quinupristin is a streptogramin B molecule whereas dalfopristin is a streptogramin A molecule.

questions.question: Which of the following binds to the P site of 50s ribosome and inhibits bacterial proteinsynthesis?
questions.explanation: Linezolid binds to the P site of the 50s ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis.It is an oxazolidinone that is active against various resistant organisms including MRSA.Linezolid is well absorbed orally and the bioavailability approaches 100%, hence intravenous andoral doses are the same for this drug.Linezolid is associated with the side effect of myelosuppression (anemia, leukopenia,pancytopenia, thrombocytopenia). Thrombocytopenia is the most common side effect. Plateletcount monitoring is done in a patient with linezolid who is at risk of myelosuppression and blooddyscrasias. Linezolid also causes serotonin syndrome due to monoamine oxidase (MAO)inhibition.

questions.question: Linezolid is approved for use in which of the following patients?
questions.explanation: •Linezolid is approved for use in the following conditions:Vancomycin-resistant E. faecium infections• Methicillin resistance/susceptible S. aureus infections• Community-acquired pneumonia due to S.pneumoniae• Nosocomial pneumonia due to S. aureus.470

questions.question: Which of the following is true about tedizolid?
questions.explanation: Tedizolid is active against gram-positive organisms.Tedizolid belongs to the class of oxazolidinones. It has poor activity against most gram-negativebacteria and anaerobes. It inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the P site of the 50S ribosomalsubunit.It is used for the treatment of skin and soft tissue infections, respiratory tract infections caused bystreptococci, and S. aureus including MRSA.Common adverse effects include myelosuppression leading to anemia, leukopenia,thrombocytopenia, and pancytopenia.471
